This diagnosis does not necessarily mean that there is a description error, but you are strongly advised to: - Read the written warning messages at the end of the data set analysis, - Check that the description is correct and whether any operators are missing. If there really is a description error, the calculated keff is not valid! ******************** IMPORTANT: RISK OF ERROR ********************

Check on the bounded nature of delta keff variances of each perturbed system ======================================================================================= This check is based on examining, for each perturbed system, the probability density function of the absolute value of the (delta keff) obtained for each cycle. A sufficient condition for the variance of the (delta keff) to be bounded is that the probability density tends to zero faster than 1 / (delta keff)^3 when (delta keff) tends to +/-infinity. That is why the asymptotic slope of the probability density function is estimated on a log-log scale. This slope must be greater than 3 (in absolute value).
The maximum value of (delta keff) obtained for all systems together is equal to $R1,ES11.5$. The variances of the (delta keff) are therefore bounded.
Probability density of the absolute value of the delta keff of the system $C1$.

The maximum absolute value of the (delta keff) obtained for each cycle is $R1,ES11.5$." It is not possible to calculate the slope for perturbed system number $N1$." However, if the maximum value of (delta keff) obtained is low, the variance can be considered to be bounded."
Estimate of slopes for each estimator of delta keff for each perturbed system
* estimator of lowest standard deviation
The minimum slope required is equal to 3. Below 3, the variance has a high probability of being unbounded.
| System | Slope* | Bounded variance |

category.message: NORMALITY TEST FOR THE DISTRIBUTION OF CYCLE KEFF VALUES
USING THE KHI2 METHOD
USING THE LILLIEFORS METHOD (~ KOLMOGOROV)
FOR EACH INDIVIDUAL ESTIMATOR

The Khi2 test, performed in MORET, tests the likelihood of the hypothesis according to which the cycle keff values must be statistically distributed according to a normal distribution if the sources are correctly placed in the fissile materials for each cycle start.

The Lilliefors test, performed in MORET, tests the likelihood of the hypothesis according to which the cycle keff values must be statistically distributed according to a normal distribution if the sources are correctly placed in the fissile materials for each cycle start.

The Khi2, calculated in MORET, compares the frequencies of the cycle keff values divided into 12 expected theoretical frequency classes (based on the assumption of an ideal gaussian distribution of the sample of cycle keff values).

The Khi2 value: - is zero when the frequencies observed are equal to the expected frequencies, i.e. @ when there is absolute agreement between the observed distribution and the expected distribution; - increases with increasing difference between the observed and expected frequencies.

For sufficiently large samples, on a normal distribution, the probability of the Khi2 statistic obtained being greater than a value x is known and tabulated as a function of x. Although the probability of obtaining a high value of the Khi2 statistic is nonzero, the lowest values are the most probable. For example, there is only a 5% chance of this value exceeding $R1,F0.3$ for a sample from a normal distribution. As we wait for the cycle keff distribution to be normal, we wait until the Khi2 statistic of the cycle keff sample is not "abnormally" high. We arbitrarily consider that values of the Khi2 statistic greater than $R1,F0.3$ are "abnormally" high because there is less than a 5% chance that a sample from a normal distribution would lead to such values.

For sufficiently large samples, on a normal distribution, the probability of the Lilliefors statistic obtained being greater than a value x is known and tabulated as a function of x. Although the probability of obtaining a high value of the Lilliefors statistic is nonzero, the lowest values are the most probable. For example, there is only a 5% chance of this value exceeding $R1,F0.3$ for a sample from a normal distribution. As we wait for the cycle keff distribution to be normal, we wait until the Lilliefors statistic of the cycle keff sample is not "abnormally" high. We arbitrarily consider that values of the Lilliefors statistic greater than $R1,F0.3$ are "abnormally" high because there is less than a 5% chance that a sample from a normal distribution would lead to such values.

A statistical test is a decision-making criterion to choose between two hypotheses: H0: the sample of cycle keff values comes from a gaussian distribution. H1: the sample of cycle keff values does not come from a gaussian distribution. It consists of setting an ARBITRARY threshold (5%), such that, when the probability associated with the value of the statistic: - is greater than the THRESHOLD, H0 is considered to be PLAUSIBLE (but not proven) and is therefore ACCEPTED; - is less than the THRESHOLD, H0 is considered to be IMPLAUSIBLE and is therefore REJECTED in favour of H1. There are two RISKS: - The risk ALPHA of wrongly rejecting the normality hypothesis (equal to the arbitrary 5% THRESHOLD); - the risk BETA of wrongly accepting the normality hypothesis. The lower the THRESHOLD (ALPHA), the higher BETA: no test is 100% reliable...
